geninfo.para: In October 1991, International introduced the Fleetrite 3+1 Battery System (Code 08MCB) on its 9000 Conventional and Cabover models. Over the last three years, this option has enjoyed widespread use.

But even though the 3+1 system has been popular among fleets and owner operators, there are still some misconceptions about what this system is capable of doing. The system's primary function is to provide three batteries for engine cranking. This ensures that a fully charged battery system is available to crank the engine even when it has been shut down with the accessories, including lights, left on.

Unlike some battery systems that were offered in the past, the three batteries used in the 3+1 system are NOT used to power electrical accessories. Rather, the accessories get their power from ONE deep cycle battery (with engine shut off) which has a capacity of about 100 amp. hours. This is roughly 1/3 less power than the standard three-battery system can provide.

The question that many operators ask is "How long does it take to recharge the accessory battery when it has been run down?" Recharge time depends on several factors, including what state of discharge the battery is in and ambient air temperature. A basic rule is that the colder the weather, the longer it will take to recharge the battery.
A graph ( Figure 1) has been provided which approximates the driving time required to recharge the accessory battery to an 80% state of charge from various levels of discharge and temperature.

The cycle life rating on the deep cycle battery is established at 50% of total discharge. As an example: A 300 cycle life rated battery will last 300 cycles if discharged 50% each discharge cycle. A 300 cycle life rated battery discharged 100% during each cycle will last approximately 1/4 of the cycle life rating.
